title: Why You Need to Start Datahoarding
content:
Have you ever wanted to watch an old YouTube video, only to find out it's been deleted? Or maybe you tried to revisit a blog or forum thread you swore you bookmarked, only to discover it has vanished without a trace. That sucks, right? It happened to me too and that’s how I got into datahoarding.

I first realized the importance of archiving things you like back in 2023, when I wanted to watch a NatGeo series called Monkey Thieves. I had memories of watching it as a little kid, and it was a pretty important part of my childhood. My favorite thing about it was its calm, soothing Hindi narration. I know almost every NatGeo series had that kind of narration, but something was different about this one. Maybe it was the contrast between the peaceful narration and the chaotic, full-of-life behavior of the monkeys that made it so unique to me.

I tried looking up the series everywhere. The only thing I could find was Season 2 on YouTube. Even NatGeo's official site doesn’t have an episode guide for the other two seasons. I eventually found a torrent with all three seasons but it was in Russian.

For now, I’ve given up hope of finding the English version let alone the Hindi version, which is the one I really want to watch. So if anyone reading this happens to have a copy of it, hit me up on Discord: @eclipse2k8.

There have been many other situations like this, where I wished I could go back in time and archive the media I really enjoyed. This is exactly why you need to start archiving data.

Buy cheap old hard drives. Use tools like wget to download webpages, JDownloader to grab multiple files off a site, and I recently found out about a tool called Copyparty, which makes it easier to host your own file server. There’s also a thriving community dedicated to this check out r/DataHoarder on Reddit.

So start datahoarding now.
